insights.summary: The system employs a mixed-reality approach with specific tasks and feedback mechanisms to enhance stroke rehabilitation.
insights.text: The rehabilitation system is designed as a proof-of-concept mixed-reality platform utilizing a Quest 3S headset and Shared Spatial Anchors to improve selective muscle activation in the arms for stroke patients. It incorporates two primary tasks: an ARAT-aligned pouring task and an MX Ink tracing task, both enhanced with visual elements like neon halos and virtual particles, and the tracing task includes haptic ticks for feedback. The system integrates visual, auditory, and haptic feedback to guide users and make the rehabilitation experience intuitive and motivational, with the ultimate goal of clinical application. A one-tap calibration UI is also included for ease of use. [c0001, d0001, c0004].

NeuroReach VR
Mixed Reality Project Proposal
Supervised by: Marwen Mokni, Christoph Bauer, Petar Lukovic
October 6, 2025
GROUP MEMBERS
Partha Sarathi
Purkayastha
Alexandre Elsig Raphael Fl¨uckiger Rakhmatillokhon
Khoshimov
I. DESCRIPTION OF THE PROJECT
Goal: To build NeuroReach VR – a proof-of-concept mixed-reality system that trains stroke reach and grasp using
an ARAT-aligned pouring task [1] and an MX Ink tracing task with visual, auditory and haptic feedback [6], to
improve selective muscle activation in the arms for stroke rehabilitation. [2].
Idea: Quest 3S with Shared Spatial Anchors pins virtual halos to a real cup and jug while MX Ink provides stylus
pose and pressure for tracing with haptic ticks via Unity SendHapticImpulse. We compute on path, time in tilt
window, spill proxy and smoothness with SPARC, and adapt difficulty to keep the user in a target corridor.
Rationale: The design draws on motor learning and control theory, emphasizing that stroke recovery combines
adaptation and skill learning to achieve specific task goals [5]. Guided by optimal feedback control, path corri-
dors, goal halos, and error-contingent cues support goal-directed corrections. Task-specific ADL movements with
validated kinematic metrics use SPARC for smoothness, while conservative auditory pacing maintains performance
consistency [3].
II. WORK PACKAGES AND TIMELINE
Hardware & Software: The system runs on Meta Quest 3S using Logitech MX Ink for precision input and haptic
feedback, with an optional Myo armband for EMG biofeedback. It is developed in Unity (C#) for Android, logs
data in CSV and JSON formats, and uses Python notebooks for quick analysis and visualization.
Work Package 1 : Data Anchors, Integration and Calibration (Weeks 1–2)
Members Responsible: R. Khoshimov, A. Elsig
Description: Set up Quest 3 passthrough and Spatial Anchors; integrate MX Ink input and haptics; implement
CSV logger. Outcomes: Unity project with anchors and passthrough; MX Ink tracing sample running with haptic
ticks; one tap calibration UI. Challenges: Anchor drift; noisy tilt estimation; inconsistent haptic support. Solutions:
Relocalize anchors at session start; low pass tilt and debounce events;. Alternatives: Use fiducials instead of anchors;
run tracing without haptics.

provenance.chunk_text:
intuitiveness of the feedback mechanisms and the motivational aspect of the gamified environment, with potential
for clinical application.
Demonstration plan: (i) Live on-headset demo with quick anchor calibration, where user performs two one minute
pouring blocks and two tracing blocks with real time halos, ticks and error bars (ii) Projected dashboard shows
on path, tilt window, spills proxy, RMS error and SPARC updated per trial to observe real-time adaptive difficulty
and fading feedback based on the user’s muscle activation. (iii) An offline video presentation showcasing the full
demonstration loop and summarized pilot metrics.
IV. *OPTIONAL MYO ARMBAND EXTENSION
Goal: EMG biofeedback for wrist extension to complement pouring and tracing [4]. Idea: Stream Myo sEMG into
Unity, compute %MVC, show twin bars with target bands, add haptic tick and buzz feedback. Rationale: Improves
engagement and selective activation. Outcome: Quick add-on with extra KPIs (time-in-target, ratio, co-contraction)
and demo toggle mode.
REFERENCES
[1] Margit Alt Murphy, Carin Will´en, and Katharina Stibrant Sunnerhagen. Movement kinematics during a drinking task are associated with
the activity capacity level after stroke. Neurorehabilitation and Neural Repair, 26(9):1106–1115, 2012.
[2] Daniel Berger and Andrea d’Avella. Myoelectric control and virtual reality to enhance motor rehabilitation after stroke. Frontiers in
Bioengineering and Biotechnology, 12:1376000, 2024.
[3] H. Huang, S. L. Wolf, and J. He. Recent developments in biofeedback for neuromotor rehabilitation. Journal of NeuroEngineering and
Rehabilitation, 3(11), 2006.
[4] H. P. Lin et al. A usability study on mobile emg-guided wrist extension training in subacute stroke patients (myoguide). Journal of
NeuroEngineering and Rehabilitation, 21:39, 2024.
[5] Maike Maier, Bel´en R. Ballester, and Paul F. M. J. Verschure. Principles of neurorehabilitation after stroke based on motor learning and
brain plasticity mechanisms. Frontiers in Systems Neuroscience, 13:74, 2019.
[6] Styrmir Saevarsson, Vala Gudmundsdottir, and Arni Kristjansson. Kinematic analysis of spiral drawing and clock drawing as measures
of upper limb function after stroke. Neuropsychological Rehabilitation, 25(5):744–763, 2015.

insights.summary: Adaptive control and performance monitoring are key features, but face challenges in implementation and accuracy.
insights.text: The system incorporates a rule-based adaptive controller that adjusts task difficulty, such as the corridor and tracing tunnel, based on user performance. Feedback gradually transitions from knowledge of performance to knowledge of results as the user progresses. A projected dashboard displays real-time metrics like 'on path' and 'tilt window,' updated per trial, allowing for observation of adaptive difficulty and fading feedback. However, challenges exist in preventing overreactive difficulty oscillations and metric drift across sessions, with proposed solutions like moving averages. [c0002, d0003, d0004, c0002].

Work Package 3 : Adaptive controller & logging (Weeks 6–8)
Members Responsible: A. Elsig, R. Fl¨uckiger
Description: Rule based adaptation of corridor, tilt window and tracing tunnel; feedback fading from knowledge of
performance to knowledge of results; Outcomes: Adaptive controller with hysteresis; 50 to 90 Hz logging with rolling
summaries. Challenges: Overreactive difficulty oscillation; metric drift across sessions. Solutions: Moving average
with gates and floors; buffered asynchronous writes and per trial files. Alternatives: Manual override switches;
lightweight local database if CSV grows; fixed difficulty presets.
Work Package 4 : Pilot study and analysis (Weeks 9–12)
Members Responsible: P. S. Purkayastha, R. Khoshimov
Description: Evaluate the system with a 5-10 participant pilot study; Test usability and performance using a baseline,
training, retention protocol to inform final refinements. Outcomes: A polished system with documentation; A formal
study protocol with a performance dataset; A completed usability and analysis report. Challenges: Participant
recruitment delays; Technical instability. Solutions: Recruit early; Conduct internal dry runs to fix bugs. Alternatives:
Use a smaller cohort; Simplify the protocol if technical issues arise.
III. OUTCOMES AND DEMONSTRATION
Expected outcomes: (i) A working proof-of-concept prototype that turns kinematics into adaptive multimodal
feedback during pouring and tracing (ii) A logging and analytics tool that summarizes on path, tilt window, spills
proxy and SPARC smoothness (iii) A small pilot indicating increased time in tilt window and reduced RMS path
error with improved SPARC, consistent with drinking task kinematics and smoothness literature [5].
Evaluation plans: (i) A preliminary usability study with physiotherapists, collecting qualitative feedback through a
think-aloud protocol and post-session questionnaires. (ii) Assess the system’s perceived effectiveness, ease of use,
and fit to ARAT aligned tasks, with specific focus on clarity of halos, ticks and result cards (iii) Focus on the
intuitiveness of the feedback mechanisms and the motivational aspect of the gamified environment, with potential
for clinical application.
Demonstration plan: (i) Live on-headset demo with quick anchor calibration, where user performs two one minute
pouring blocks and two tracing blocks with real time halos, ticks and error bars (ii) Projected dashboard shows
on path, tilt window, spills proxy, RMS error

provenance.chunk_text: Challenge on claim c0001: The evidence does not specify how the system will address the challenges of overreactive difficulty oscillation and metric drift across sessions. The claim states the system aims to improve selective muscle activation for stroke rehabilitation. However, evidence E1 outlines challenges in Work Package 3, specifically 'Overreactive difficulty oscillation' and 'metric drift across sessions.' While solutions like 'Moving average with gates and floors' are mentioned, it's unclear if these solutions are sufficient or fully developed to guarantee a stable and effective rehabilitation experience, which is crucial for stroke patients who may have varying recovery rates and sensitivities.

provenance.chunk_text: Challenge on claim c0002: The claim describes adaptive difficulty and fading feedback, but the evidence only partially details the adaptive controller's functions. The claim (c0002) asserts that the system will observe real-time adaptive difficulty and fading feedback based on user muscle activation [E2], and that the adaptive controller will adjust the corridor, tilt window, and tracing tunnel based on performance, fading feedback from knowledge of performance to knowledge of results [E3]. Evidence E2 mentions 'adaptive difficulty' and 'fading feedback' as outcomes. However, the specific mechanisms of how the controller adjusts 'corridor', 'tilt window', and 'tracing tunnel' based on 'performance' and the transition from 'knowledge of performance' to 'knowledge of results' are not fully elaborated in the provided snippets. The evidence does not explicitly link muscle activation to the adaptive difficulty or feedback fading.

provenance.chunk_text: Challenge on claim c0003: The claim mentions 'noisy tilt estimation' and suggests low-pass filtering as a solution, but the evidence discusses 'metric drift across sessions' and proposes 'moving average with gates and floors' as a solution, which is a different approach. The claim (E4) identifies 'noisy tilt estimation' as a potential challenge and proposes 'low-pass filtering' as a solution. However, evidence E1, which also discusses challenges and solutions, mentions 'metric drift across sessions' as a challenge and suggests 'moving average with gates and floors' as a solution. While both relate to data smoothing, 'metric drift' is a broader issue than just noisy tilt estimation, and 'moving average with gates and floors' is a more complex solution than simple low-pass filtering. It's unclear if these are addressing the same underlying problem or different ones.

provenance.chunk_text: Challenge on claim c0002: The claim mentions a projected dashboard with specific metrics, but the evidence only partially supports this by listing some of those metrics. The claim (c0002) states that a projected dashboard will display metrics such as 'on path, tilt window, spills proxy, RMS error, and SPARC', updated per trial. Evidence E1 mentions 'on path, time in tilt window, spill proxy' as being computed. Evidence E2 mentions 'on path, tilt window and spill proxy' as outcomes of the pouring task and 'tracing with tunnel and live error' for the tracing task. However, 'RMS error' and 'SPARC' are not explicitly mentioned in the provided evidence snippets. Therefore, the completeness of the dashboard's metrics as described in the claim is not fully substantiated.

insights.summary: Technical challenges in mixed-reality implementation, particularly with spatial anchors and sensor data, require robust solutions.
insights.text: Several technical challenges are identified that could impact the system's usability and effectiveness in guiding users through tasks like pouring and tracing. These include potential anchor drift, noisy tilt estimation, and inconsistent haptic support. Proposed solutions involve relocalizing anchors at the session start, applying low-pass filtering and debouncing to tilt estimation, and considering alternatives like fiducials or omitting haptics if primary solutions are insufficient. These issues directly affect the accuracy and reliability of the mixed-reality guidance. [c0003, d0002, c0001].

NeuroReach VR
Mixed Reality Project Proposal
Supervised by: Marwen Mokni, Christoph Bauer, Petar Lukovic
October 6, 2025
GROUP MEMBERS
Partha Sarathi
Purkayastha
Alexandre Elsig Raphael Fl¨uckiger Rakhmatillokhon

I. DESCRIPTION OF THE PROJECT
Goal: To build NeuroReach VR – a proof-of-concept mixed-reality system that trains stroke reach and grasp using
an ARAT-aligned pouring task [1] and an MX Ink tracing task with visual, auditory and haptic feedback [6], to
improve selective muscle activation in the arms for stroke rehabilitation. [2].
Idea: Quest 3S with Shared Spatial Anchors pins virtual halos to a real cup and jug while MX Ink provides stylus
pose and pressure for tracing with haptic ticks via Unity SendHapticImpulse. We compute on path, time in tilt
window, spill proxy and smoothness with SPARC, and adapt difficulty to keep the user in a target corridor.
Rationale: The design draws on motor learning and control theory, emphasizing that stroke recovery combines
adaptation and skill learning to achieve specific task goals [5]. Guided by optimal feedback control, path corri-
dors, goal halos, and error-contingent cues support goal-directed corrections. Task-specific ADL movements with
validated kinematic metrics use SPARC for smoothness, while conservative auditory pacing maintains performance
consistency [3].
II. WORK PACKAGES AND TIMELINE
Hardware & Software: The system runs on Meta Quest 3S using Logitech MX Ink for precision input and haptic
feedback, with an optional Myo armband for EMG biofeedback. It is developed in Unity (C#) for Android, logs
data in CSV and JSON formats, and uses Python notebooks for quick analysis and visualization.

run tracing without haptics.

actions.title: Investigate the efficacy of proposed solutions for adaptive control stability
actions.detail: The evidence acknowledges challenges with overreactive difficulty oscillation and metric drift across sessions (c0001, d0003). While solutions like moving averages with gates and floors are proposed (d0003), the specific implementation and empirical validation of these solutions for the pouring and tracing tasks are not detailed. Further investigation is needed to confirm if these methods effectively prevent oscillations and drift in the context of the ARAT-aligned pouring and MX Ink tracing tasks.

actions.title: Hypothesize the impact of anchor drift mitigation on user experience
actions.detail: Relocalizing anchors at session start is proposed to address anchor drift (c0003, d0002). However, the frequency and intrusiveness of this relocalization process are not specified. It's hypothesized that frequent or complex relocalization could disrupt the user's flow and negatively impact the motivational aspect of the rehabilitation (c0001, d0004). Future work should explore user feedback on the relocalization process.

actions.title: Develop a comprehensive dashboard visualization strategy
actions.detail: The projected dashboard is intended to display various metrics (c0002, d0004). While some metrics are listed, the evidence does not fully detail the dashboard's design or how it will visually represent the adaptive difficulty and fading feedback in a way that is intuitive and motivational for users (d0004). A next step should be to design and prototype the dashboard, focusing on clear and actionable visualizations of these key performance indicators and adaptive changes.

actions.title: Clarify the relationship between tilt estimation solutions and metric drift
actions.detail: There appears to be a discrepancy or lack of clarity regarding the solutions for tilt estimation and metric drift. 'Noisy tilt estimation' is mentioned with a solution of low-pass filtering (c0003, d0002), while 'metric drift across sessions' is addressed with moving averages (d0003). It's unclear if noisy tilt estimation directly contributes to metric drift and if the proposed solutions are complementary or independent. Clarification is needed on how these technical challenges are interconnected and how the proposed solutions address them holistically.

challenges.claim_text: The system aims to improve selective muscle activation in the arms for stroke rehabilitation through tasks like pouring and tracing. [E1]. It utilizes a mixed-reality approach, incorporating visual, auditory, and haptic feedback to guide users. [E1]. The project focuses on building a proof-of-concept system that aligns with the ARAT-aligned pouring task and an MX Ink tracing task. [E1]. The goal is to provide an intuitive and motivational rehabilitation experience, with potential for clinical application. [E2].
challenges.summary: The evidence does not specify how the system will address the challenges of overreactive difficulty oscillation and metric drift across sessions.
challenges.detail: The claim states the system aims to improve selective muscle activation for stroke rehabilitation. However, evidence E1 outlines challenges in Work Package 3, specifically 'Overreactive difficulty oscillation' and 'metric drift across sessions.' While solutions like 'Moving average with gates and floors' are mentioned, it's unclear if these solutions are sufficient or fully developed to guarantee a stable and effective rehabilitation experience, which is crucial for stroke patients who may have varying recovery rates and sensitivities.

However, evidence E1, which also discusses challenges and solutions, mentions 'metric drift across sessions' as a challenge and suggests 'moving average with gates and floors' as a solution. While both relate to data smoothing, 'metric drift' is a broader issue than just noisy tilt estimation, and 'moving average with gates and floors' is a more complex solution than simple low-pass filtering. It's unclear if these are addressing the same underlying problem or different ones.

Work Package 3 : Adaptive controller & logging (Weeks 6–8)
Members Responsible: A. Elsig, R. Fl¨uckiger
Description: Rule based adaptation of corridor, tilt window and tracing tunnel; feedback fading from knowledge of
performance to knowledge of results; Outcomes: Adaptive controller with hysteresis; 50 to 90 Hz logging with rolling
summaries. Challenges: Overreactive difficulty oscillation; metric drift across sessions. Solutions: Moving average
with gates and floors; buffered asynchronous writes and per trial files. Alternatives: Manual override switches;
lightweight local database if CSV grows; fixed difficulty presets.
Work Package 4 : Pilot study and analysis (Weeks 9–12)
Members Responsible: P. S. Purkayastha, R. Khoshimov
Description: Evaluate the system with a 5-10 participant pilot study; Test usability and performance using a baseline,
training, retention protocol to inform final refinements. Outcomes: A polished system with documentation; A formal
study protocol with a performance dataset; A completed usability and analysis report. Challenges: Participant
recruitment delays; Technical instability. Solutions: Recruit early; Conduct internal dry runs to fix bugs. Alternatives:
Use a smaller cohort; Simplify the protocol if technical issues arise.
III. OUTCOMES AND DEMONSTRATION
Expected outcomes: (i) A working proof-of-concept prototype that turns kinematics into adaptive multimodal
feedback during pouring and tracing (ii) A logging and analytics tool that summarizes on path, tilt window, spills
proxy and SPARC smoothness (iii) A small pilot indicating increased time in tilt window and reduced RMS path
error with improved SPARC, consistent with drinking task kinematics and smoothness literature [5].
Evaluation plans: (i) A preliminary usability study with physiotherapists, collecting qualitative feedback through a
think-aloud protocol and post-session questionnaires. (ii) Assess the system’s perceived effectiveness, ease of use,
and fit to ARAT aligned tasks, with specific focus on clarity of halos, ticks and result cards (iii) Focus on the
intuitiveness of the feedback mechanisms and the motivational aspect of the gamified environment, with potential
for clinical application.
Demonstration plan: (i) Live on-headset demo with quick anchor calibration, where user performs two one minute
pouring blocks and two tracing blocks with real time halos, ticks and error bars (ii) Projected dashboard shows
on path, tilt window, spills proxy, RMS error
